catalyst.context: Converting CO 2 into renewable solar fuel using photocatalysts is one of the most ideal solutions for environmental challenges and energy crises.Here, the solid-solid Z-scheme Zn 0.5 Cd 0.5 S/Aug-C 3 N 4 (ZCS/AuCN) heterojunction showed improved photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 due to the enhanced visible light consumption, fast dissolution of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, quick interfacial transfer process of electrons, and enlarged surface area.Under visible-light irradiation, methanol (CH 3 OH) was produced at a rate of 1.31 mol h -1 g -1 over ZCS/AuCN, roughly 43.6 and 32.7 folds higher than those observed over pure ZCS and CN samples.The analytical characterization results verified the role of AuNPs as an electron mediator, which improved the rapid extraction of photoinduced electrons and enhanced the reduction ability of CO 2 .This work not only demonstrates a facile photodeposition assisted hydrothermal method for fabrication of Zn x Cd 1-x S/ AuC 3 N 4 heterojunction composite photocatalysts but also demonstrates the possibility of utilizing ternary composites for enhanced photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 .

(China) and used as received.Zinc acetate (0.9 mmol) and cadmium acetate (0.9 mmol) were dispersed in 60 mL of distilled water and stirred for 30 min, followed by the addition of thiourea (45 mmol) and stirred for additional 30 min.Finally, the resultant solution was transferred to a 100 m L-Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and maintained at 150 C for 5 h.After the reaction, the obtained yellow powder was centrifuged, washed with ethanol and distilled water several times, and then dried under vacuum at 70 C for 8 h. The g-C 3 N 4 sample was prepared by a modified copolymerization technique reported previously 32.In a typical preparation process, 6.0 g dicyandiamide and 0.3 g barbituric acid were grounded together and dispersed in 30 mL of water and heated at 90 C until the water was removed.The as-prepared solid powder was heated up to 550 C for 4 h at a heating rate of 5 C min -1 to obtain bulk g-C 3 N 4 .Finally, the obtained g-C 3 N 4 was crushed into fine particles for further use. In a typical synthesis process, 0.2 g of ZCS catalyst was dispersed in 50 mL water and ultrasonicated for 10 min.Then, HAuCl 4 .4H 2 O solution containing 1 wt Au was dropped into ZCS solution and, after adjusting the pH level to about 7 with 1 mmol NaOH, the mixture was placed under light irradiation (300 W Xe lamp) for 1 h to obtain metallic gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) deposited over ZCS nanospheres.After this stage, the solution was cleaned with ethanol and subsequently with distilled water, then dried under vacuum at 60 C for 6 h.The obtained sample was labeled as ZCS/Au nanospheres. The ZCS/AuCN catalysts were obtained via a dual-plot self-assembly method.In a typical synthesis, 5 wt g-C 3 N 4 powder was mixed with 30 mL methanol and ultrasonicated for 1 h, the resultant exfoliated g-C 3 N 4 thin sheets solution was mixed with 0.2 g of the above synthesized AuNPs loaded ZCS nanospheres (ZCS/Au) dispersion and stirred at room temperature for 24 h.The remaining methanol was eliminated by the nitrogen stream.The zeta potential of CN at pH 7 was characterized as -33.1 mV, and for ZCS as 8.7 mV, while the zeta potential of ZCS/Au sampled was 0.57 mV and thus, the negative charged CN could easily wrap over the surface of positively charged ZCS/Au nanospheres to form a core-shell heterojunction by simple continuous stirring.The obtained brownish red solid was collected and dried under vacuum at 70 C for 6 h.Another ZCSCN sample was fabricated using a similar procedure as above except the photodepostion of AuNPs was performed over the surface of ZCS nanospheres.Further, a CN/Au sample was prepared by dispersing bulk CN into 30 mL methanol and ultrasonically treated for 1 h, the exfoliated thin sheets solution of CN was washed several times with ethanol and water, then dried under vacuum at 60 C for 6 h.The as-prepared exfoliated thin sheets of CN catalyst were redispersed in 30 mL water and HAuCl 4 .4H 2 O solution containing 1 wt Au.The pH level was adjusted to about 7 using 1 mmol NaOH, then, the mixture was placed under Xe lamp (300 W) light irradiation for 1 h to obtain metallic AuNPs deposited CN nanosheets.After this stage, the solution was collected and washed with ethanol and distilled water several times, then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 C for 6 h.The prepared sample was marked as CN/Au nanosheets.For comparative photocatalytic study, ZCS was physically mixed with CN and labeled as ZCN.Also, the above prepared ZCS/Au nanospheres were physically mixed with CN and labeled as ZNA. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) was obtained using a Rigaku D/max-2500 X-ray diffractometer.The surface morphology was observed using a Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JSM-7500 F, JEOL, Japan) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) were conducted using a FEI Talos F200X electron microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX).The molar ration of Zn and Cd in Zn x Cd 1-x S were determined using inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS), (Optima 4300 DV spectrometer, Perkin Elmer) and the values are present in results and discussion section.The electron spin resonance (ESR) technique was adopted to determine the reactive species signals by Bruker EMX premium X instrument (USA) using 5-dimethly-1 pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) as spin trapping agent.The reactive species were detected using a spectrometer following visible light irradiation to obtain the DMPO-O 2 and DMPO- OH electro paramagnetic resonance (EPR) signals.The BET specific surface areas of the powder samples were tested using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 nitrogen adsorption apparatus (USA).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was tested by an ultrahigh vacuum VG ESCALAB 210 electron spectrometer.Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were conducted using an IR Affinity-1 FTIR spectrometer (Shimadzu, Japan).UV-vis absorbance spectra of prepared photocatalysts were acquired from a Shimadzu UV-2550 UV-vis spectrophotometer (Japan) using BaSO 4 as the standard for reflectance spectra. The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction property was examined in a 200 mL-Pyrex reactor under the ambient temperature and pressure.The photocatalyst preparation and testing conditions followed the same procedure according to literature 33.In detail, 50 mg of catalyst sample was uniformly dispersed into 15 mL deionized water by ultrasonication in 200 mL homemade Pyrex reactor and dried at 80 C for 2 h to evaporate water and deposition of sample on the bottom of the reactor forming a smooth thin film.The openings of the reactor were sealed with rubber stoppers, and N 2 gas was passed through the reactor (30 min) to ensure complete anaerobic condition within the reactor system before light irradiation.The mixture of CO 2 and H 2 O vapor were in situ generated by the reaction of NaHCO 3 (0.084 g added into the reactor before seal) and H 2 SO 4 aqueous solution (0.3 mL, 0.2 M) which was introduced into the reactor using a syringe before light irradiation.A 300 W Xe lamp with a UV-cutoff filter ( 420 nm) was used as a light source and placed at a distance of 15 cm over the photocatalytic reactor.After one hour of light irradiation, the CO 2 reduced products were analyzed by a Shimadzu GC-2014C gas chromatograph (Japan) equipped with a flame ionized detector and methanizer. Photocurrents were calculated by a CHI CHI660C electrochemical analyzer (China) in a standard three-electrode arrangement.The apparatus and method used for these measurements have been described in detail elsewhere 33.

co-catalyst.context: A novel all-solid-solid Z-scheme hierarchical ZCS/AuCN heterojunction was prepared as a highly efficient catalyst for visible-lightinduced CO 2 reduction to solar fuel.AuNPs were photodeposited onto the ZCS surface followed by wrapping thin 2D g-C 3 N 4 nanosheets over ZCS surface.These unique geometrical architectural and compositional features of the photocatalytic system contained several advantages, such as reducing diffusion length and improved electrical conductivity for charge separation and transportation, large surface area, and effective sites for photoredox catalysis.Consequently, the close contact interface of AuNPs with ZCS and CN substantially improved the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with a high CH 3 OH evolution rate (1.31 mol h -1 g -1 ), which is roughly 43.6 and 32.7 times more than those of pure ZCS and CN samples.The addition of AuNPs not only assisted the charge separation in both ZCS and CN but also advanced the reduction ability of photoinduced electrons in the conduction band of CN.Our findings demonstrate that the synthesis of all solid-solid Zscheme ZCS/AuCN heterojunctions can be a competent frontier to attain extremely active materials for CO 2 photo-reduction; such strategy can be further extended to other solar-energy related applications. light source.context: A novel all-solid-solid Z-scheme hierarchical ZCS/AuCN heterojunction was prepared as a highly efficient catalyst for visible-lightinduced CO 2 reduction to solar fuel.AuNPs were photodeposited onto the ZCS surface followed by wrapping thin 2D g-C 3 N 4 nanosheets over ZCS surface.These unique geometrical architectural and compositional features of the photocatalytic system contained several advantages, such as reducing diffusion length and improved electrical conductivity for charge separation and transportation, large surface area, and effective sites for photoredox catalysis.Consequently, the close contact interface of AuNPs with ZCS and CN substantially improved the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with a high CH 3 OH evolution rate (1.31 mol h -1 g -1 ), which is roughly 43.6 and 32.7 times more than those of pure ZCS and CN samples.The addition of AuNPs not only assisted the charge separation in both ZCS and CN but also advanced the reduction ability of photoinduced electrons in the conduction band of CN.Our findings demonstrate that the synthesis of all solid-solid Zscheme ZCS/AuCN heterojunctions can be a competent frontier to attain extremely active materials for CO 2 photo-reduction; such strategy can be further extended to other solar-energy related applications. (China) and used as received.Zinc acetate (0.9 mmol) and cadmium acetate (0.9 mmol) were dispersed in 60 mL of distilled water and stirred for 30 min, followed by the addition of thiourea (45 mmol) and stirred for additional 30 min.Finally, the resultant solution was transferred to a 100 m L-Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and maintained at 150 C for 5 h.After the reaction, the obtained yellow powder was centrifuged, washed with ethanol and distilled water several times, and then dried under vacuum at 70 C for 8 h. The g-C 3 N 4 sample was prepared by a modified copolymerization technique reported previously 32.In a typical preparation process, 6.0 g dicyandiamide and 0.3 g barbituric acid were grounded together and dispersed in 30 mL of water and heated at 90 C until the water was removed.The as-prepared solid powder was heated up to 550 C for 4 h at a heating rate of 5 C min -1 to obtain bulk g-C 3 N 4 .Finally, the obtained g-C 3 N 4 was crushed into fine particles for further use. In a typical synthesis process, 0.2 g of ZCS catalyst was dispersed in 50 mL water and ultrasonicated for 10 min.Then, HAuCl 4 .4H 2 O solution containing 1 wt Au was dropped into ZCS solution and, after adjusting the pH level to about 7 with 1 mmol NaOH, the mixture was placed under light irradiation (300 W Xe lamp) for 1 h to obtain metallic gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) deposited over ZCS nanospheres.After this stage, the solution was cleaned with ethanol and subsequently with distilled water, then dried under vacuum at 60 C for 6 h.The obtained sample was labeled as ZCS/Au nanospheres. The ZCS/AuCN catalysts were obtained via a dual-plot self-assembly method.In a typical synthesis, 5 wt g-C 3 N 4 powder was mixed with 30 mL methanol and ultrasonicated for 1 h, the resultant exfoliated g-C 3 N 4 thin sheets solution was mixed with 0.2 g of the above synthesized AuNPs loaded ZCS nanospheres (ZCS/Au) dispersion and stirred at room temperature for 24 h.The remaining methanol was eliminated by the nitrogen stream.The zeta potential of CN at pH 7 was characterized as -33.1 mV, and for ZCS as 8.7 mV, while the zeta potential of ZCS/Au sampled was 0.57 mV and thus, the negative charged CN could easily wrap over the surface of positively charged ZCS/Au nanospheres to form a core-shell heterojunction by simple continuous stirring.The obtained brownish red solid was collected and dried under vacuum at 70 C for 6 h.Another ZCSCN sample was fabricated using a similar procedure as above except the photodepostion of AuNPs was performed over the surface of ZCS nanospheres.Further, a CN/Au sample was prepared by dispersing bulk CN into 30 mL methanol and ultrasonically treated for 1 h, the exfoliated thin sheets solution of CN was washed several times with ethanol and water, then dried under vacuum at 60 C for 6 h.The as-prepared exfoliated thin sheets of CN catalyst were redispersed in 30 mL water and HAuCl 4 .4H 2 O solution containing 1 wt Au.The pH level was adjusted to about 7 using 1 mmol NaOH, then, the mixture was placed under Xe lamp (300 W) light irradiation for 1 h to obtain metallic AuNPs deposited CN nanosheets.After this stage, the solution was collected and washed with ethanol and distilled water several times, then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 C for 6 h.The prepared sample was marked as CN/Au nanosheets.For comparative photocatalytic study, ZCS was physically mixed with CN and labeled as ZCN.Also, the above prepared ZCS/Au nanospheres were physically mixed with CN and labeled as ZNA. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) was obtained using a Rigaku D/max-2500 X-ray diffractometer.The surface morphology was observed using a Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JSM-7500 F, JEOL, Japan) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) were conducted using a FEI Talos F200X electron microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX).The molar ration of Zn and Cd in Zn x Cd 1-x S were determined using inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS), (Optima 4300 DV spectrometer, Perkin Elmer) and the values are present in results and discussion section.The electron spin resonance (ESR) technique was adopted to determine the reactive species signals by Bruker EMX premium X instrument (USA) using 5-dimethly-1 pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) as spin trapping agent.The reactive species were detected using a spectrometer following visible light irradiation to obtain the DMPO-O 2 and DMPO- OH electro paramagnetic resonance (EPR) signals.The BET specific surface areas of the powder samples were tested using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 nitrogen adsorption apparatus (USA).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was tested by an ultrahigh vacuum VG ESCALAB 210 electron spectrometer.Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were conducted using an IR Affinity-1 FTIR spectrometer (Shimadzu, Japan).UV-vis absorbance spectra of prepared photocatalysts were acquired from a Shimadzu UV-2550 UV-vis spectrophotometer (Japan) using BaSO 4 as the standard for reflectance spectra. The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction property was examined in a 200 mL-Pyrex reactor under the ambient temperature and pressure.The photocatalyst preparation and testing conditions followed the same procedure according to literature 33.In detail, 50 mg of catalyst sample was uniformly dispersed into 15 mL deionized water by ultrasonication in 200 mL homemade Pyrex reactor and dried at 80 C for 2 h to evaporate water and deposition of sample on the bottom of the reactor forming a smooth thin film.The openings of the reactor were sealed with rubber stoppers, and N 2 gas was passed through the reactor (30 min) to ensure complete anaerobic condition within the reactor system before light irradiation.The mixture of CO 2 and H 2 O vapor were in situ generated by the reaction of NaHCO 3 (0.084 g added into the reactor before seal) and H 2 SO 4 aqueous solution (0.3 mL, 0.2 M) which was introduced into the reactor using a syringe before light irradiation.A 300 W Xe lamp with a UV-cutoff filter ( 420 nm) was used as a light source and placed at a distance of 15 cm over the photocatalytic reactor.After one hour of light irradiation, the CO 2 reduced products were analyzed by a Shimadzu GC-2014C gas chromatograph (Japan) equipped with a flame ionized detector and methanizer. Photocurrents were calculated by a CHI CHI660C electrochemical analyzer (China) in a standard three-electrode arrangement.The apparatus and method used for these measurements have been described in detail elsewhere 33.
